head.title: Elegy III.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 11-13.

l.emph: I gaze with rapture on your charms, but sigh
To think that others may that rapture share.

lg.l: Beneath a verdant willow’s grateful shade,
Upon the margin of a murm’ring stream,
Young Damon33 Virgilian pastoral name found in Eclogue 8. Cf. also Milton, "Epitaphium Damonis" in Poems (1645). (once) a hapless swain was laid,

And fair Lavinia44 Daughter of King Latinus and wife of Aeneas in Virgil’s Aeneid; daughter of Titus in William Shakespeare’s Titus Andronicus (1589); but more probably relating to the Palemon and Lavinia episode from James Thomson's "Autumn." was his constant theme.
Begin my Muse (he said) a mournful song,
And let my sheep and goats at random stray;
Ye breezes, bear the mournful sound along,
And to Lavinia ev’ry note convey.
Say, false Lavinia, lovely charmer tell
How long must I endure this load of wo?
Say, must I still in shades of sorrow dwell,
And must my briny tears for ever flow?
Canst thou unmov’d behold my ling’ring grief,
And slight my gen’rous passion with disdain?
’Tis thou alone can give my soul relief—
One soothing smile could soften all my pain.
In vain, the sports and pastimes of the plain
Would cheer my heart, and wonted peace restore;
Now ev’n the charms of music are in vain,
How can they please, when thou art kind no more!
Still at the revel or the mazy dance,
Where oft with thee I wanton’d o'er the green;
There do I see a rival youth advance,
And take the place where Damon should have been.
Go on, false nymph, and frolic out the day,
And let my rival’s happiness o’erflow,
Whilst I through wilds and lonely deserts stray,
In sad despair not knowing where I go.
Some lonely cave, or gloomy place I’ll find,
Where fairies revel in the briery dell;
There vent the sad ideas of my mind,
And bid the joys of love and life farewell.
